body_html:
Thanks @jart. I had found that one already and it wasn't the case, but it surely could have been.

For the lost souls that end up here, the reason why this was happening is that I (wrongly) assumed that the Bazel repo for apt would work just fine for Ubuntu 18.04, but it did not (and severly, too). In fact, installing bazel that way overwrote some critical paths of the openjdk-8-jre or oracle-java8-installer installations, leaving basic functionalities such as keytool unaccessible. The fix was to remove bazel, uninstall / reinstally java, and simply use the recommended installer from Bazel's website, which does not raise these issues. Also, if you don't use Bazel for anything else, I would recommend installing it locally your home folder and with its own openjdk install, which reduces all the java mess to a bare minimum.

Thanks @jart. I had found that one already and it wasn't the case, but it surely could have been. 

For the lost souls that end up here, the reason why this was happening is that I (wrongly) assumed that the Bazel repo for `apt` would work just fine for Ubuntu 18.04, but it did not (and severly, too). In fact, installing `bazel` that way overwrote some critical paths of the `openjdk-8-jre` or `oracle-java8-installer` installations, leaving basic functionalities such as `keytool` unaccessible. The fix was to remove bazel, uninstall / reinstally java, and simply use the recommended installer from Bazel's website, which does not raise these issues. Also, if you don't use Bazel for anything else, I would recommend installing it locally your home folder and with its own `openjdk` install, which reduces all the java mess to a bare minimum.
